body_html: The documentation (https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.12/tutorials/mnist/beginners/index.html) says that mnist.test.images is 10k images, while mnist.train.images is 55k images. By feeding the entire training set at once, it seems likely that you're causing too much memory to be allocated, and that may be your problem. 8GB is not a lot of RAM these days. In linux you can use ulimit to bound the memory permitted to a process.

In linux you can use ulimit to bound the memory permitted to a process.
body: The documentation (https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.12/tutorials/mnist/beginners/index.html) says that mnist.test.images is 10k images, while mnist.train.images is 55k images.  By feeding the entire training set at once, it seems likely that you're causing too much memory to be allocated, and that may be your problem.  8GB is not a lot of RAM these days.   In linux you can use ulimit to bound the memory permitted to a process.
